article.title: Arsenal_F.C.
article.paragraph: Arsenal Football Clubis a professionalassociation footballfootballclub based inHolloway, London. The club play in thePremier League, the top flight of English football. One of theFootball records in England#Total titles won (1871present)most successful clubsin English football, they have won 13Football League First DivisionFirst Divisionand Premier League titles and a record 12FA Cups.

Founded in 1886, Arsenal became the first club from the south of England to jointhe Football Leaguein 1893. They won five League Championships and two FA Cups in the 1930s and became the second club to win theDouble (association football)League and FA Cup Doublein the 20th century in the1970-71 in English football1971. In the 1990s and 2000s, Arsenal won a Cup Double, two further League and FA Cup Doubles, went through the200304 Arsenal F.C. season200304 league seasonundefeated and became the first London club to reach the2006 UEFA Champions League FinalUEFA Champions League Final.

The club's colours are traditionally red and white. Founded inWoolwich, south-east London, in 1913 they moved north across the city toArsenal StadiuminHighbury. In 2006, they moved to theEmirates Stadiumin nearby Holloway. Arsenal contest theNorth London derbywith rivalsTottenham Hotspur F.C.Tottenham Hotspur.

Arsenal has one of the highest incomes and largest fanbases in the world.cite newsO'ConnorAshlingLiverpool lag in fight for global fan supremacy as TV row growshttp://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/sport/football/premierleague/article3192868.ece25 June 2014The Times13 October 2011cite webFootball Money Leaguehttp://www.deloitte.com/view/en_GB/uk/industries/sportsbusinessgroup/sports/football/deloitte-football-money-league/deloitte.comDeloitte25 June 2014January 2014The club was named theForbes' list of the most valuable football clubsseventh most valuable association football club, valued at $1.3 billion, in 2015.cite webSoccer Team Valueshttp://www.forbes.com/soccer-valuations/list/forbes.comForbesOctober 15, 2015May 2014
article.heading: History

template.arg: [[History of Arsenal F.C. (1886–1966)]] and [[History of Arsenal F.C. (1966–present)]]

link.target: File:Woolwich Arsenal v. Newcastle United, April 1906.jpg
link.part: Woolwich Arsenal (in dark shirts) playingNewcastle United F.C.Newcastle United(in striped shirts) in anFA Cupsemi-final  the club's first ever  at theVictoria Ground (Stoke)Victoria Ground,Stoke-on-TrentStoke.

article.paragraph:
Arsenal Football Club were formed as Dial Square in 1886 by workers at theRoyal ArsenalinWoolwich, south-east London, and were renamed Royal Arsenal shortly afterwards.cite bookPhilSoarMartinTylerThe Official Illustrated History of ArsenalHamlyn200523978-0-600-61344-2yThe club were renamed again to Woolwich Arsenal after becoming alimited companyin 1893.cite webhttp://homepage.ntlworld.com/andy.kelly/arsenal/record/namechange.htm Royal Arsenal becomes Woolwich Arsenal Andy Kelly's Arsenal Resource Website 13 October 2010
The club became the first southern member ofthe Football Leaguein 1893, starting out in theFootball League Second DivisionSecond Division, and won promotion to theFootball League First DivisionFirst Divisionin 1904. The club's relative geographic isolation resulted in lower attendances than those of other clubs, which led to the club becoming mired in financial problems and effectively bankrupt by 1910, when they were taken over by businessmenHenry Norris (businessman)Henry Norrisand William Hall.cite bookSoar & Tyler2005The Official Illustrated History of Arsenal32–33Norris sought to move the club elsewhere, and in 1913, soon after relegation back to the Second Division, Arsenal moved to the newArsenal StadiuminHighbury, North London; they dropped "Woolwich" from their name the following year.cite bookSoar & Tyler2005The Official Illustrated History of Arsenal40Arsenal only finished in fifth place in the second division during the last pre-war competitive season of 191415, but were nevertheless elected to rejoin the First Division when competitive football resumed in 191920, at the expense of local rivalsTottenham Hotspur F.C.Tottenham Hotspur. Some books have reported that this election to division 1 was achieved by dubious means.It has been alleged that Arsenal's promotion, on historical grounds rather than merit, was thanks to underhand actions by Norris, who was chairman of the club at the time; seeHistory of Arsenal F.C. (18861966)for more details. These allegations range from political machinations to outright bribery; no firm proof of any wrongdoing has ever been found. A brief account is given incite bookSoar & Tyler2005The Official Illustrated History of Arsenal40A more detailed account can be found incite bookSpurlingJonRebels for the Cause: The Alternative History of Arsenal Football ClubMainstream2004978-1-84018-900-138–41

Arsenal appointedHerbert Chapmanas manager in 1925. Having already won the league twice withHuddersfield Town F.C.Huddersfield Townin192324 Football League192324and192425 Football League192425(seeFootball in England#Seasons in English footballSeasons in English football), Chapman brought Arsenal their first period of major success. His revolutionary tactics and training, along with the signings of star players such asAlex James (footballer)Alex JamesandCliff Bastin, laid the foundations of the club's domination of English football in the 1930s.cite bookSoar & Tyler2005The Official Illustrated History of Arsenal18Under his guidance Arsenal won their first major trophies  victory in the1930 FA Cup Finalpreceded two League Championships, in193031 Football League193031and193233 Football League193233. In addition, Chapman was behind the 1932 renaming of the localLondon Undergroundstation from "Gillespie Road" to "Arsenal tube stationArsenal", making it the only Tube station to be named specifically after a football club.cite webhttp://www.tfl.gov.uk/static/corporate/media/newscentre/archive/3709.htmlLondon Underground and Arsenal present The Final Salute to HighburyTransport for London12 January 200612 August 2011

link.target: File:Arsenal FC Football and Premier League performance.PNG
link.part: Chart showing the progress of Arsenal's league finishes since the 189394 season

article.paragraph: Chapman died suddenly ofpneumoniain early 1934, leavingJoe Shaw (footballer born 1883)Joe ShawandGeorge Allisonto carry on his successful work. Under their guidance, Arsenal won three more titles, in193334 Football League193334,193435 Football League193435and193738 Football League193738, and the193536 FA Cup1936 FA Cupwhile also becoming known as the "Bank of England club." As key players retired, Arsenal had started to fade by the decade's end, and then the intervention of the Second World War meant competitive professional football in England was suspended.cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/history/herbert-chapman/arsenal-clinch-a-hat-trick-of-titles Arsenal clinch a hat-trick of titles Arsenal F.C 27 November 2009https://web.archive.org/web/20100106081811/http://www.arsenal.com/history/herbert-chapman/arsenal-clinch-a-hat-trick-of-titles6 January 2010nocite bookChampions all! TonyBrown SoccerDataNottingham 1-905891-02-4 2007 6–7 http://www.soccer.mistral.co.uk/books/ch6-10.pdf

After the war, Arsenal enjoyed a second period of success under Allison's successorTom Whittaker (footballer)Tom Whittaker, winning the league in194748 Football League194748and195253 Football League195253, and the FA Cup in194950 FA Cup1950. Their fortunes waned thereafter; unable to attract players of the same calibre as they had in the 1930s, the club spent most of the 1950s and 1960s in trophyless mediocrity. Even formerEngland national football teamEnglandcaptainBilly Wright (footballer born 1924)Billy Wrightcould not bring the club any success as manager, in a stint between 1962 and 1966.cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/history/post-war-arsenal/post-war-arsenal-overview Post-War Arsenal – Overview Arsenal F.C 27 November 2009cite bookChampions all! Brown 2007 7

Arsenal began winning silverware again with the surprise appointment of clubphysiotherapistBertie Meeas manager in 1966. After losing twoFootball League CupLeague Cupfinals, they won their first European trophy, the196970 Inter-Cities Fairs Cup. This was followed by an even greater triumph: their first197071 Football LeagueLeagueand197071 FA CupFA CupDouble (association football)doublein197071 in English football197071.cite webhttp://www.nationalfootballmuseum.com/hall-of-fame/profiles/entry/bertie-mee/ Bertie Mee Football Hall of Fame National Football Museum RobertGalvin 23 October 2009This marked a premature high point of the decade; the Double-winning side was soon broken up and the following decade was characterised by a series of near misses, starting with Arsenal finishing as FA Cup runners up in197172 FA Cup1972, and First Division runners-up in197273 Football League197273.

Terry Neillwas recruited by the Arsenal board to replaceBertie Meeon 9 July 1976 and at the age of 34 he became the youngest Arsenal manager to date. With new signings likeMalcolm MacdonaldandPat Jennings, and a crop of talent in the side such asLiam BradyandFrank Stapleton, the club enjoyed their best form since the 1971 double, reaching a trio of FA Cup finals (197778 FA Cup1978,197879 FA Cup1979and197980 FA Cup1980), and losing the1980 European Cup Winners' Cup Finalonpenalty shootout (association football)penalties. The club's only success during this time was a last-minute 32 victory over Manchester United in the1979 FA Cup Final, widely regarded as a classic.cite webhttp://www.fchd.info/ARSENAL.HTM Arsenal Football Club History Database Richard Rundle 23 October 2009https://web.archive.org/web/20091106003337/http://fchd.info/ARSENAL.HTM6 November 2009noA 2005 poll of English football fans rated the 1979 FA Cup Final the 15th greatest game of all time. Reference:cite newshttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xmlClassic final? More like a classic five minutes WinterHenry Daily Telegraph 19 April 2005 11 August 2008 London

The return of former playerGeorge Graham (footballer)George Grahamas manager in 1986 brought a third period of glory. Arsenal won the League Cup in198687 Football League Cup1987, Graham's first season in charge. This was followed by a League title win in198889 Football League198889, won with a last-minute goal in theLiverpool 02 Arsenal (26 May 1989)final game of the seasonagainst fellow title challengersLiverpool F.C.Liverpool. Graham's Arsenal won another title in199091 Football League199091, losing only one match, won the199293 FA CupFA Cupand199293 Football League CupLeague Cupdouble in 1993, and a second European trophy, theEuropean Cup Winners' Cup, in199394 European Cup Winners' Cup1994.cite newshttp://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11670_3335042,00.html Top Ten: Title Run-ins AndyClarke Sky Sports 26 March 20097 December 2009
Graham's reputation was tarnished when he was found to have taken kickbacks from agentRune Haugefor signing certain players,Graham was banned for a year by the Football Association for his involvement in the scandal after he admitted he had received an "unsolicited gift" from Hauge. Reference:cite newshttp://football.guardian.co.uk/News_Story/0,,148114,00.html Rune Hauge, international man of mystery The Guardian CollinsRoy 18 March 2000 11 August 2008 London The case is given a detailed treatment incite bookBowerTom Broken Dreams Simon & Schuster 2003 978-0-7434-4033-2and he was dismissed in 1995. His replacement,Bruce Rioch, lasted for only one season, leaving the club after a dispute with the board of directors.cite newshttp://www.independent.co.uk/sport/rioch-at-odds-with-the-system-1309564.html Rioch at odds with the system The Independent MooreGlenn 13 August 1996 23 October 2009 London

File:Arsenal open top bus parade 2004.jpgrightthumbArsenal's players and fans celebrate their 2004 League title win with an open-top bus parade.alt=A group of people on a red open-topped bus wave to a crowd of onlookers.The club's success in the late 1990s and first decade of the 21st century owed a great deal to the 1996 appointment ofArsne Wengeras manager. Wenger brought new tactics, a new training regime and several foreign players who complemented the existing English talent. Arsenal won a second League and Cup double in199798 Arsenal F.C. season199798and a third in200102 Arsenal F.C. season200102. In addition, the club reached the final of the19992000 UEFA Cup(losing on penalties toGalatasaray S.K. (football team)Galatasaray), were victorious in the200203 FA Cup2003and200405 FA Cup2005FA Cups, and won the Premier League in200304 FA Premier League200304without losing a single match, an achievement which earned the side the nickname "The Invincibles (football)The Invincibles".cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/a/arsenal/3713537.stm Arsenal the Invincibles BBC Sport HughesIan 15 May 2004 11 August 2008 The feat came within a run of 49 league matches unbeaten from 7 May 2003 to 24 October 2004, aFootball records in Englandnational record.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/a/arsenal/3950453.stm Arsenal run ends at 49 FraserAndrew BBC Sport 25 October 2004 27 August 2008

Arsenal finished in either first or second place in the league in eight of Wenger's first eleven seasons at the club, although on no occasion were they able to retain the title.As of July 2013, they were one of only five teams, the others being Manchester United,Blackburn Rovers F.C.Blackburn Rovers,Chelsea F.C.Chelsea, andManchester City F.C.Manchester City, to have won the Premier League since its formation in 1992.cite webhttp://www.rsssf.com/tablese/engchamp.html#c1993 FA Premier League Champions 1993–2007 Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation RossJames M 11 August 2008
https://web.archive.org/web/20080922085028/http://www.rsssf.com/tablese/engchamp.html22 September 2008noArsenal had never progressed beyond the quarter-finals of theUEFA Champions LeagueChampions Leagueuntil200506 UEFA Champions League200506; in that season they became the first club from London in the competition's fifty-year history to reach2006 UEFA Champions League Finalthe final, in which they were beaten 21 byFC BarcelonaBarcelona.In July 2006, they moved into theEmirates Stadium, after 93 years at Highbury.cite newshttp://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/article691484.ece Farewell Bergkamp, hello future The TimesUK AizlewoodJohn 23 July 2006 23 October 2009

Arsenal reached the final of the2007 Football League Cup Final2007and2011 Football League Cup Final2011League Cups, losing 21 to Chelsea andBirmingham City F.C.Birmingham Cityrespectively. The club had not gained a major trophy since the 2005 FA Cup until 17 May 2014, when Arsenal beatHull City A.F.C.Hull Cityin the2014 FA Cup Final, coming back from a 20 deficit to win the match 32.cite newshttp://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/may/18/arsene-wenger-fa-cup-arsenal-hull-trophy-drought Arséne Wenger savours FA Cup win over Hull as Arsenal end drought The GuardianUK HytnerDavid 18 May 2014 21 May 2014This qualified them for the2014 FA Community Shieldwhere they would play Premier League champions Manchester City. They recorded a resounding 30 win in the game, winning their second trophy in three months.cite newshttp://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/aug/10/arsenal-manchester-city-community-shield Arsenal cruise to Community Shield win over weakened Manchester City The GuardianUK RonayBarney 10 August 2014 1 November 2014Nine months after their Community Shield triumph, Arsenal appeared in the FA Cup final for the second year in a row, thrashingAston Villa F.C.Aston Villa40 in the2015 FA Cup Finalfinaland becoming the most successful club in the tournament's history with 12 titles.cite newshttp://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/may/30/fa-cup-final-arsenal-aston-villa-alexis-sanchez Alexis Sánchez inspires Arsenal to win over Aston Villa The GuardianUK TaylorDaniel 30 May 2015 30 May 2015On 2 August 2015 Arsenal beat Chelsea 10 atWembley Stadiumto retain the Community Shield and earn their 14th Community Shield title.cite newshttp://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33667216 Arsenal 1–0 Chelsea BBCUK CryerAndy 2 August 2015 4 August 2015
article.heading: Crest
article.paragraph: Unveiled in 1888, Royal Arsenal's firstcrest (sports)crestfeatured threecannonviewed from above, pointing northwards, similar to thecoat of armsof theMetropolitan Borough of Woolwich(nowadays transferred to thecoat of arms of the Royal Borough of Greenwich). These can sometimes be mistaken for chimneys, but the presence of a carved lion's head and acascabel (artillery)cascabelon each are clear indicators that they are cannon.cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/history/the-crestThe CrestArsenal F.C11 August 2008https://web.archive.org/web/20080812085724/http://www.arsenal.com/history/the-crest12 August 2008noThis was dropped after the move to Highbury in 1913, only to be reinstated in 1922, when the club adopted a crest featuring a single cannon, pointing eastwards, with the club's nickname,The Gunners, inscribed alongside it; this crest only lasted until 1925, when the cannon was reversed to point westward and its barrel slimmed down.

In 1949, the club unveiled a modernised crest featuring the same style of cannon below the club's name, set inblackletter, and above the coat of arms of theMetropolitan Borough of Islingtonand a scroll inscribed with the club's newly adopted Latinmotto,Victoria Concordia Crescit"victory comes from harmony", coined by the club's programme editor Harry Homer.For the first time, the crest was rendered in colour, which varied slightly over the crest's lifespan, finally becoming red, gold and green. Because of the numerous revisions of the crest, Arsenal were unable tocopyrightit. Although the club had managed to register the crest as a trademark, and had fought (and eventually won) a long legal battle with a local street trader who sold "unofficial" Arsenal merchandise,cite web''Arsenal v. Reed'' in the Court of Appeal Michael Simkins LLP http://www.simkins.co.uk/ebulletins/DAFArsenalReed.aspx FreeDominic 4 June 2003 11 August 2008 Arsenal eventually sought a more comprehensive legal protection. Therefore, in 2002 they introduced a new crest featuring more modern curved lines and a simplified style, which was copyrightable.cite newsArsenal go for a makeover BBC Sport http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/a/arsenal/1795444.stm 1 February 2004 11 August 2008
The cannon once again faces east and the club's name is written in asans-seriftypeface above the cannon. Green was replaced by dark blue. The new crest was criticised by some supporters; the Arsenal Independent Supporters' Association claimed that the club had ignored much of Arsenal's history and tradition with such a radical modern design, and that fans had not been properly consulted on the issue.cite webCrestfallen http://www.aisa.org/pdfs/crest_leaflet.pdf Arsenal Independent Supporters' Association 11 August 2008 https://web.archive.org/web/20061108191039/http://www.aisa.org/pdfs/crest_leaflet.pdf 8 November 2006 PDF

Until the 1960s, a badge was worn on the playing shirt only for high-profile matches such as FA Cup finals, usually in the form of amonogramof the club's initials in red on a white background.cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/the-arsenal-shirt-badge The Arsenal shirt badge Arsenal F.C 24 January 2010

The monogram theme was developed into anArt Deco-style badge on which the letters A and C framed a football rather than the letter F, the whole set within a hexagonal border. This early example of a corporate logo, introduced as part of Herbert Chapman's rebranding of the club in the 1930s, was used not only on Cup Final shirts but as a design feature throughout Highbury Stadium, including above the main entrance and inlaid in the floors.cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/the-art-deco-crest The Art Deco crest Arsenal F.C 24 January 2010
From 1967, a white cannon was regularly worn on the shirts, until replaced by the club crest, sometimes with the addition of the nickname "The Gunners", in the 1990s.

In the 201112 season, Arsenal celebrated their 125th year anniversary. The celebrations included a modified version of the current crest worn on their jerseys for the season. The crest was all white, surrounded by 15oakleaves to the right and 15Laurel wreathlaurelleaves to the left. The oak leaves represent the 15 founding members of the club who met at the Royal Oak pub. The 15 laurel leaves represent the design detail on the six pence pieces paid by the founding fathers to establish the club. The laurel leaves also represent strength. To complete the crest, 1886 and 2011 are shown on either sides of the motto "Forward" at the bottom of the crest.cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/125-years-in-the-making-anniversary-crest 125th anniversary crest Arsenal F.C 1 May 2011
article.heading: Colours

template.arg: Dark red shirt, white shorts, socks with blue and white stripes
A dark-red shirt, white shorts and socks with blue and white stripes
Arsenal's original home colours. The team wore a similar kit (but with redcurrant socks) during the [[2005–06 Arsenal F.C. season|2005–06]] season.

article.paragraph: For much of Arsenal's history, their home colours have been bright red shirts with white sleeves and white shorts, though this has not always been the case. The choice of red is in recognition of a charitable donation fromNottingham Forest F.C.Nottingham Forest, soon after Arsenal's foundation in 1886. Two of Dial Square's founding members,Fred BeardsleyandMorris Bates, were former Forest players who had moved to Woolwich for work. As they put together the first team in the area, no kit could be found, so Beardsley and Bates wrote home for help and received a set of kit and a ball.The shirt was redcurrant, a dark shade of red, and was worn with white shorts and socks with blue and white hoops.cite webThe Arsenal home kithttp://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/the-arsenal-kit28 October 2012cite webhttp://www.historicalkits.co.uk/Arsenal/Arsenal.htm Arsenal Historical Football Kits D & M Moor 8 December 2006

In 1933, Herbert Chapman, wanting his players to be more distinctly dressed, updated the kit, adding white sleeves and changing the shade to a brighterpillar boxred. Two possibilities have been suggested for the origin of the white sleeves. One story reports that Chapman noticed a supporter in the stands wearing a red sleeveless sweater over a white shirt; another was that he was inspired by a similar outfit worn by the cartoonistTom Webster (cartoonist)Tom Webster, with whom Chapman played golf.cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/history/kit-design Arsenal Kit Design Arsenal F.C 8 November 2008
https://web.archive.org/web/20081019003758/http://www.arsenal.com/history/kit-design19 October 2008noRegardless of which story is true, the red and white shirts have come to define Arsenal and the team have worn the combination ever since, aside from two seasons. The first was 196667, when Arsenal wore all-red shirts;this proved unpopular and the white sleeves returned the following season. The second was 200506, the last season that Arsenal played at Highbury, when the team wore commemorative redcurrant shirts similar to those worn in 1913, their first season in the stadium; the club reverted to their normal colours at the start of the next season.In the 200809 season, Arsenal replaced the traditional all-white sleeves with red sleeves with a broad white stripe.

Arsenal's home colours have been the inspiration for at least three other clubs. In 1909,AC Sparta PragueSparta Pragueadopted a dark red kit like the one Arsenal wore at the time;in 1938,Hibernian F.C.Hibernianadopted the design of the Arsenal shirt sleeves in their own green and white strip.cite webhttp://www.historicalkits.co.uk/Scottish_Football_League/Hibernian/hibernian.htm Hibernian Historical Football Kits D & M Moor 11 August 2008
https://web.archive.org/web/20080821120715/http://historicalkits.co.uk/Scottish_Football_League/Hibernian/hibernian.htm21 August 2008noIn 1920,S.C. BragaSporting Clube de Braga's manager returned from a game at Highbury and changed his team's green kit to a duplicate of Arsenal's red with white sleeves and shorts, giving rise to the team's nickname ofOs Arsenalistas.cite newshttps://video.uefa.com/news/newsidSecret of Braga's success UEFA 21 October 2005 Rui Matos Pereira 23 January 2011These teams still wear those designs to this day.

For many years Arsenal's away colours were white shirts and either black or white shorts. In the 196970 season, Arsenal introduced an away kit of yellow shirts with blue shorts. This kit was worn in the1971 FA Cup Finalas Arsenal beat Liverpool to secure theDouble (association football)doublefor the first time in their history.cite newshttp://www.historicalkits.co.uk/English_Football_League/FA_Cup_Finals/index.htmlFA Cup Finals4 October 2013Historical Football KitsArsenal reached the1972 FA Cup FinalFA Cup finalagain the following year wearing the red and white home strip and were beaten byLeeds United A.F.C.Leeds United. Arsenal then competed in three consecutive FA Cup finals between1978 FA Cup Final1978and1980 FA Cup Final1980wearing their "lucky" yellow and blue strip,which remained the club's away strip until the release of a green and navy away kit in 198283. The following season, Arsenal returned to the yellow and blue scheme, albeit with a darker shade of blue than before.

WhenNike, Inc.Niketook over fromAdidasas Arsenal's kit provider in 1994, Arsenal's away colours were again changed to two-tone blue shirts and shorts. Since the advent of the lucrative replica kit market, the away kits have been changed regularly, with Arsenal usually releasing both away and third choice kits. During this period the designs have been either all blue designs, or variations on the traditional yellow and blue, such as the metallic gold and navy strip used in the 200102 season, the yellow and dark grey used from 2005 to 2007, and the yellow and maroon of 2010 to 2013.cite webhttp://www.historicalkits.co.uk/Arsenal/Arsenal-change-kits.html Arsenal Change Kits Historical Football Kits D & M Moor 27 November 2009
As of 2009, the away kit is changed every season, and the outgoing away kit becomes the third-choice kit if a new home kit is being introduced in the same year.cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/the-club/corporate-info/the-club-charter Club Charter Arsenal F.C 23 October 2009
article.heading: Kit manufacturers and shirt sponsors
article.paragraph: Arsenal's shirts have been made by manufacturers includingBukta(from the 1930s until the early 1970s),Umbro(from the 1970s until 1986),Adidas(19861994),Nike, Inc.Nike(19942014), andPuma SEPuma(from 2014).cite newsArsenal agree £30m-a-year deal with Puma in most lucrative kit contract in Britainhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2321029/Arsenal-sign-30m-year-deal-Puma-years-2013-14.html9 September 2013Daily Mail8 May 2013LondonDavidKentLike those of most other major football clubs, Arsenal's shirts have featured sponsors' logos since the 1980s; sponsors includeJVC(19821999),Sega(19992002),Telefnica EuropeO2(20022006), andEmirates (airline)Emirates(from 2006).
article.heading: Stadiums
article.paragraph: MainEmirates StadiumFile:Arsenal Stadium interior North Bank.jpgthumbleftThe North Bank Stand,Arsenal Stadium,Highburyalt=A grandstand at a sports stadium. The seats are predominantly red.For most of their time in south-east London, Arsenal played at theManor Ground, PlumsteadManor GroundinPlumstead, apart from a three-year period at the nearbyInvicta Groundbetween 1890 and 1893. The Manor Ground was initially just a field, until the club installed stands andterrace (stadium)terracingfor their first Football League match in September 1893. They played their home games there for the next twenty years (with two exceptions in the 189495 season), until the move to North London in 1913.cite bookInglisSimonSimon InglisFootball Grounds of Britain19853rd1996CollinsWillowLondon0-00-218426-516–17cite newsSuspension of the Plumstead GroundThe Times7 February 18956

Widely referred to as Highbury,Arsenal Stadiumwas the club's home from September 1913 until May 2006. The original stadium was designed by the renowned football architectArchibald Leitch, and had a design common to many football grounds in the UK at the time, with a single covered stand and three open-air banks of terracing.cite webhttp://www.islington.gov.uk/DownloadableDocuments/Environment/Pdf/highburyconservationplan_2005.pdf A Conservation Plan for Highbury Stadium, London Islington Council February 2005 11 August 2008PDFhttps://web.archive.org/web/20080910062128/http://www.islington.gov.uk/DownloadableDocuments/Environment/Pdf/highburyconservationplan_2005.pdf10 September 2008noThe entire stadium was given a massive overhaul in the 1930s: newArt DecoWest and East stands were constructed, opening in 1932 and 1936 respectively, and a roof was added to the North Bank terrace, which was bombed during the Second World War and not restored until 1954.

Highbury could hold more than 60,000 spectators at its peak, and had a capacity of 57,000 until the early 1990s. TheTaylor Reportand Premier League regulations obliged Arsenal to convert Highbury to an all-seater stadium in time for the 199394 season, thus reducing the capacity to 38,419 seated spectators.cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/article.asp?thisNavhttps://web.archive.org/web/20080111223345/http://www.arsenal.com/article.asp?thisNav11 January 2008 Highbury Arsenal F.C This capacity had to be reduced further duringUEFA Champions LeagueChampions Leaguematches to accommodate additional advertising boards, so much so that for two seasons, from 1998 to 2000, Arsenal played Champions League home matches atWembley Stadium (1923)Wembley, which could house more than 70,000 spectators.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sport/football/138932.stmArsenal get Wembley go-aheadBBC Sport24 July 199811 August 2008

File:Emirates Stadium Arsenal.jpgthumbrightTheEmirates Stadiumfilling up on the day ofDennis Bergkamp's testimonialalt=An interior view of a football stadium. There are no players on the pitch but there are spectators in the stands.Expansion of Highbury was restricted because the East Stand had been designated as a Grade IIlisted buildingand the other three stands were close to residential properties.These limitations prevented the club from maximising matchday revenue during the 1990s and first decade of the 21st century, putting them in danger of being left behind in the football boom of that time.cite newshttp://www.independent.co.uk/sport/arsenal-consider-leaving-hallowed-marble-halls-1246012.htmlArsenal consider leaving hallowed marble hallsThe IndependentClareGarner18 August 199723 October 2009LondonAfter considering various options, in 2000 Arsenal proposed building a new 60,361-capacity stadium at Ashburton Grove, since named theEmirates Stadium, about 500 metres south-west of Highbury.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/a/arsenal/1011234.stmArsenal unveil new stadium plansBBC Sport7 November 200011 August 2008The project was initially delayed by red tape and rising costs,cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/a/arsenal/2953273.stmArsenal stadium delayBBC Sport16 April 200311 August 2008and construction was completed in July 2006, in time for the start of the 200607 season.cite newsBergkamp given rousing farewellBBC Sporthttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/a/arsenal/5203954.stm22 July 200623 August 2007The stadium was named after its sponsors, the airline companyEmirates (airline)Emirates, with whom the club signed the largest sponsorship deal in English football history, worth around 100 million;cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/a/arsenal/3715678.stmArsenal name new groundBBC Sport5 October 200411 August 2008some fans referred to the ground as Ashburton Grove, or the Grove, as they did not agree with corporate sponsorship of stadium names.cite webhttp://www.arsenal-world.co.uk/news/loadnews.asp?cidThe 'E' WordArsenal WorldDawesBrian2006Footymad11 August 2008The stadium will be officially known as Emirates Stadium until at least 2028, and the airline will be the club's shirt sponsor until the end of the 201819 season.cite newsRiachJamesArsenal's new Emirates sponsorship deal to fund transfers and salarieshttp://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2012/nov/23/arsenal-emirates-airline-sponsorship-deal17 December 2012The Guardian23 November 2012LondonFrom the start of the 201011 season on, the stands of the stadium have been officially known as North Bank, East Stand, West Stand and Clock end.Emirates Stadium stands to be renamedArsenal FC, 19 July 2010

Arsenal's players train at theShenley Training Centrein Hertfordshire, a purpose-built facility which opened in 1999.cite newshttp://www.architectsjournal.co.uk/arsenal-gets-a-complex/774448.article Arsenal gets a complex The Architects' Journal DavidTaylor 21 October 199920 January 2010Before that the club used facilities on a nearby site owned by theUniversity College London UnionUniversity College of London Students' Union. Until 1961 they had trained at Highbury.cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/the-club/training-centre The Training Centre Arsenal F.C 11 August 2008https://web.archive.org/web/20080812090836/http://www.arsenal.com/the-club/training-centre12 August 2008noArsenal'sArsenal F.C. AcademyAcademy under-18teams play their home matches at Shenley, while theArsenal F.C. Reservesreservesplay their games atMeadow Park (Borehamwood)Meadow Park,cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/youth-sides-set-to-play-at-meadow-parkYouth sides to play at Meadow Park30 July 2013which is also the home ofBorehamwood F.C.Boreham Wood F.C..
article.heading: Supporters
article.paragraph: detailsArsenal F.C. supportersFile:Laurent Koscielny clashes with Heurelho Gomes.jpgthumbleftArsenal against rivals Tottenham, known as theNorth London derby, in November 2010.Arsenal fans often refer to themselves as "Gooners", the name derived from the team's nickname, "The Gunners". The fanbase is large and generally loyal, and virtually all home matches sell out; in 200708 Arsenal had the second-highest average League attendance for an English club (60,070, which was 99.5% of available capacity),cite webhttp://www.tonykempster.co.uk/prematt.htm?compAttendances 2007/08Kempster, Tony11 August 2008and as of 2006, the fourth-highest all-time average attendance.cite webhttp://www.nufc.com/html/attendance-all-time.html https://web.archive.org/web/20071029153705/http://www.nufc.com/html/attendance-all-time.html 29 October 2007 All Time League Attendance Records NUFC.com 11 August 2008Please note that some pre-war attendance figures used by this source were estimates and may not be entirely accurate.Arsenal have the seventh highestAverage attendances of European football clubsaverage attendance of European football clubsonly behindBorussia Dortmund,FC Barcelona,Manchester United F.C.Manchester United,Real Madrid C.F.Real Madrid,FC Bayern MunichBayern Munich, andFC Schalke 04Schalke.cite webhttp://soccernet.espn.go.com/stats/attendance/_/league/ger.1/year/2010/german-bundesliga?ccGerman Bundesliga Stats: Team Attendance – 2010–11[[ESPNsoccernet]]cite webhttp://arxiu.fcbarcelona.cat/web/english/noticies/club/temporada10-11/05/17/n110517117527.htmlCamp Nou: Average attendance 79,390 | FCBarcelona.catArxiu.fcbarcelona.cat17 May 201113 August 2012cite webhttp://soccernet.espn.go.com/stats/attendance/_/league/eng.1/year/2010/barclays-premier-league?ccBarclays Premier League Stats: Team Attendance – 2010–11[[ESPNsoccernet]]cite webhttp://soccernet.espn.go.com/stats/attendance/_/league/ESP.1/year/2010/spanish-primera-division?ccSpanish La Liga Stats: Team Attendance – 2010–11[[ESPNsoccernet]]The club's location, adjoining wealthy areas such asCanonburyandBarnsbury, mixed areas such asIslington,Holloway, LondonHolloway,Highbury, and the adjacentLondon Borough of Camden, and largely working-class areas such asFinsbury Park, LondonFinsbury ParkandStoke Newington, has meant that Arsenal's supporters have come from a variety of social classes.

File:Arsenal Flag (7100433493).jpgthumbArsenal supportersLike all major English football clubs, Arsenal have a number of domestic supporters' clubs, including the Arsenal Football Supporters' Club, which works closely with the club, and the Arsenal Independent Supporters' Association, which maintains a more independent line. TheArsenal Supporters' Trustpromotes greater participation in ownership of the club by fans. The club's supporters also publishfanzinessuch asThe Gooner,Gunflashand the satiricalUp The Arse!. In addition to the usual Englishfootball chants, supporters sing "One-Nil to the Arsenal" (to the tune of "Go West (song)Go West") and "Boring, Boring Arsenal", which used to be a common taunt from opposition fans but is now sung ironically by Arsenal supporters when the team is playing well.cite newshttp://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,353528,00.html Boring, Boring Arsenal Time 22 September 2002 NobleKate 11 August 2008

There have always been Arsenal supporters outside of London, and since the advent of satellite television, a supporter's attachment to a football club has become less dependent on geography. Consequently, Arsenal have a significant number of fans from beyond London and all over the world; in 2007, 24 UK, 37 Irish and 49 other overseas supporters clubs were affiliated with the club.cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/assets/_files/documents/jul_08/gun__1215526755_charter_report_20062007.docWord documentFans Report 2006/2007Arsenal F.C7 September 2008https://web.archive.org/web/20080910062129/http://www.arsenal.com/assets/_files/documents/jul_08/gun__1215526755_charter_report_20062007.doc10 September 2008noA 2005 report by Granada Ventures, which at the time owned a 9.9% stake in the club, estimated Arsenal's global fanbase at 27 million.cite webArsenal FC – the Premiership's fastest growing football brand Granada Ventures http://www.granadaventures.co.uk/newsdocs/doc28.doc https://web.archive.org/web/20070604205337/http://www.granadaventures.co.uk/newsdocs/doc28.doc 4 June 2007 Word document 5 August 2005

Arsenal's longest-running and deepest rivalry is with their nearest major neighbours,Tottenham Hotspur F.C.Tottenham Hotspur; matches between the two are referred to asNorth London derbyNorth London derbies.cite webhttp://www.premierleague.com/page/Magazinedettail/0,,12306~1195275,00.htmlThe North London derbyStewartCogginPremier League7 September 2008https://web.archive.org/web/20080808134127/http://www.premierleague.com/page/Magazinedettail/0,,12306~1195275,00.html8 August 2008noOther rivalries within London include those withChelsea F.C.Chelsea,Fulham F.C.FulhamandWest Ham United F.C.West Ham United. In addition, Arsenal and Manchester United developed a strong on-pitch rivalry in the late 1980s, which intensified in recent years when both clubs were competing for the Premier League titlecite webhttp://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/clubfootball/news/newsidThe Classic: Arsenal-Manchester Utd FIFA 17 January 200723 October 2009  so much so that a 2003online pollby theFootball Fans Censuslisted Manchester United as Arsenal's biggest rivals, followed by Tottenham and Chelsea.cite webhttp://www.footballfanscensus.com/issueresults/Club_Rivalries_Uncovered_Results.pdfClub Rivalries Uncovered[[Football Fans Census]]7 September 2008PDFhttps://web.archive.org/web/20080910061502/http://www.footballfanscensus.com/issueresults/Club_Rivalries_Uncovered_Results.pdf10 September 2008noA 2008 poll listed the Tottenham rivalry as more important.cite webhttp://www.footballpools.com/football-fever/rivalries-league.htmlFootball Rivalries Report 2008The New Football Pools7 September 2008
article.heading: Ownership and finances
article.paragraph: detailsOwnership of Arsenal F.C.Arsenal's parent company, Arsenal Holdings plc, operates as afinancial quotenon-quotedpublic limited company, whose ownership is considerably different from that of other football clubs. Only 62,217 shares in Arsenal have been issued,cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/assets/_files/documents/jul_08/gun__1215525940_Arsenal_Annual_Report_May_2007.pdfPDFStatement of Accounts and Annual Report 2006/2007 (p43)Arsenal Holdings plcMay 200711 August 2008https://web.archive.org/web/20080910062131/http://www.arsenal.com/assets/_files/documents/jul_08/gun__1215525940_Arsenal_Annual_Report_May_2007.pdf10 September 2008nocite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/assets/_files/documents/sep_10/gun__1285660177_Arsenal_Holdings_plc_Annual_Re.pdfPDFStatement of Accounts and Annual Report 2009/2010 (p41)Arsenal Holdings plcSep 201012 January 2011and they are not traded on a public exchange such as theFTSE GroupFTSEorAlternative Investment MarketAIM; instead, they are traded relatively infrequently on theICAP (company)ICAPSecurities and Derivatives Exchange, a specialist market. On 6 November 2014, a single share in Arsenal had amid priceof 14,500, which set the club'smarket capitalisationvalue at approximately 902.2m.cite webArsenal Holdings plc ICAP http://www.isdx.com/forcompanies/ourcompanies/companydetail/default.aspx?securityid6 November 2014 The club made a pre-taxoperating profit(excluding player transfers) of 62.7m in the year ending 31 May 2009, from a turnover of 313.3m.cite webArsenal Holdings plc: 2009 Financial results Arsenal Holdings plc http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/arsenal-holdings-plc-results-for-year-end-ma 28 September 20095 November 2009

The largest shareholder on the Arsenal board is American sports tycoonStan Kroenke, who launched a bid for the club in 2007,cite newsTakeover gains pace at Arsenal with 9.9% salehttp://football.guardian.co.uk/News_Story/0,,2051488,00.htmlThe GuardianScott, Matt and Allen, Katie6 April 200711 August 2008Londonand in November 2009 increased his holding to 18,594 shares (29.9%).cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/kroenke-increases-stake-in-arsenal-holdingsKroenke increases stake in Arsenal HoldingsArsenal F.C5 November 20096 December 2009 https://web.archive.org/web/20091108092200/http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/kroenke-increases-stake-in-arsenal-holdings8 November 2009no

A rival bid to Kroenke's came from Red & White Securities, which is co-owned by Russian billionaireAlisher Usmanovand Iranian London-based financierFarhad Moshiri (businessman)Farhad Moshiri.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/6971124.stm BBC News Russian buys Dein's Arsenal stake 30 August 2007 11 August 2008
Red & White launched its bid in August 2007, buying the stake held by former Arsenal vice-chairmanDavid Dein, and as of October 2013 owned 18,671 shares (30%) in the club.cite webhttp://www.bloomberg.com/article/2013-10-17/aI.lgF6W0rlo.htmlArsenal Holdings PLC: Holding(s) in CompanyBloomberg17 October 201326 January 2015This led to press speculation of a bidding war between Kroenke and Usmanov.However, Kroenke agreed not to purchase more than 29.9% of the club until at least September 2009,cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/otherKroenke joins Arsenal's Board of DirectorsArsenal F.C19 September 200819 September 2008https://web.archive.org/web/20080919202625/http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/other19 September 2008nowhile the rest of the board have first option on each other's shares until October 2012.cite newshttp://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/board-announce-revised-lock-down-agreementArsenal board announce revised 'lock-down' agreementArsenal F.C18 October 200711 August 2008

As of October 2011, Kroenke owns 41,574 shares (66.82%) and Red & White Securities own 18,261 shares (29.35%).cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/the-club/corporate-info/the-arsenal-boardThe Arsenal Board | Corporate Info | The ClubArsenal.com13 July 201113 August 2012Under company law Kroenke, as majority shareholder, is obliged to make an offer for the remaining shares in the club.

Ivan Gazidishas been the club's Chief Executive since 2009.cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/the-club/corporate-info/the-arsenal-boardThe Arsenal Board | Corporate Info | The BoardArsenal.com5 February 201311 August 2014
article.heading: In popular culture
article.paragraph:
Arsenal have appeared in a number of media "firsts". On 22 January 1927, their match at Highbury againstSheffield United F.C.Sheffield Unitedwas the first English League match to be broadcast live on radio.Firsts, Lasts & Onlys: Football  Paul Donnelley (Hamlyn, 2010)cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/programme-it-happened-at-highbury It Happened at Highbury: First live radio broadcast Arsenal F.C 11 August 2008 A decade later, on 16 September 1937, an exhibition match between Arsenal's first team and the reserves was the first football match in the world to be televised live.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/funny_old_game/2260280.stm Happened on this day – 16 September BBC Sport 16 September 200211 August 2008
Arsenal also featured in the first edition of theBBC'sMatch of the Day, which screened highlights of their match against Liverpool atAnfieldon 22 August 1964.cite newsHistory of Match of the Day http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/tv_and_radio/match_of_the_day/879960.stm BBC Sport 14 February 200311 August 2008
British Sky BroadcastingBSkyB's coverage of Arsenal's January 2010 match againstManchester United F.C.Manchester Unitedwas the first live public broadcast of a sports event on3D television.cite newsFans trial first live 3D sports event http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-sport/fans-trial-first-live-3d-sports-event-20100201-n7bo.html Associated Press Sydney Morning Herald 1 February 201016 March 2010

As one of the most successful teams in the country, Arsenal have often featured when football is depicted in the arts in Britain. They formed the backdrop to one of the earliest football-related films,The Arsenal Stadium Mystery(1939).cite webhttp://www.imdb.com/title/tt0031055/ The Arsenal Stadium Mystery IMDb 11 August 2008
The film centres on afriendly matchbetween Arsenal and an amateur side, one of whose players is poisoned while playing. Many Arsenal players appeared as themselves and managerGeorge Allisonwas given a speaking part.More recently, the bookFever PitchbyNick Hornbywas an autobiographical account of Hornby's life and relationship with football and Arsenal in particular. Published in 1992, it formed part of the revival and rehabilitation of football in British society during the 1990s.cite newshttp://www.guardian.co.uk/books/2008/jun/13/nick.hornbyNick HornbyThe Guardian22 July 20087 September 2008Critically acclaimed and commercial dynamite, Fever Pitch helped to make football trendy and explain its appeal to the soccerlessLondonThe book was twice adapted for the cinema  theFever Pitch (1997 film)1997 British filmfocuses on Arsenal's 198889 title win,cite webhttp://www.imdb.com/title/tt0119114/Fever Pitch (1997)IMDb7 September 2008https://web.archive.org/web/20081015195547/http://imdb.com/title/tt0119114/15 October 2008noand aFever Pitch (2005 film)2005 American versionfeatures a fan of baseball'sBoston Red Sox.cite webhttp://www.imdb.com/title/tt0332047/Fever Pitch (2005)IMDb7 September 2008

Arsenal have often been stereotyped as adefender (association football)defensiveand "boring" side, especially during the 1970s and 1980s;cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/3037789.stmNo more boring, boring ArsenalJohnMayBBC Sport19 May 20037 September 2008many comedians, such asEric Morecambe, made jokes about this at the team's expense. The theme was repeated in the 1997 filmThe Full Monty, in a scene where the lead actors move in a line and raise their hands, deliberately mimicking the Arsenal defence'soffside trap, in an attempt to co-ordinate theirstripteaseroutine.cite webhttp://www.arseweb.com/other/movies.html Arsenal at the movies Arseweb 11 August 2008
https://web.archive.org/web/20080726182708/http://www.arseweb.com/other/movies.html26 July 2008noAnother film reference to the club's defence comes in the filmPlunkett & Macleane, in which two characters are named Dixon and Winterburn after Arsenal's long-serving full backs  the right-sidedLee Dixonand the left-sidedNigel Winterburn.

The 1991 television comedy sketch showHarry Enfield & Chumsfeatured a sketch from the characters Mr Cholmondly-Warner and Grayson where the Arsenal team of 1933, featuring exaggerated parodies of fictitious amateur players take on the Liverpool team of 1991.Association Football  Harry Enfield  Mr Cholmondley-WarnerYouTube
article.heading: In the community
article.paragraph: In 1985, Arsenal founded acorporate social responsibilitycommunity scheme, "Arsenal in the Community", which offered sporting,social inclusion, educational and charitable projects. The club support a number of charitable causes directly and in 1992 established The Arsenal Charitable Trust, which by 2006 had raised more than 2 million for local causes.cite newshttp://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/arsenal-charity-ball-raises-over-pound-60-000Arsenal Charity Ball raises over £60,000Arsenal F.C11 May 200611 August 2008An ex-professional and celebrity football team associated with the club also raised money by playing charity matches.cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/the-club/community/ex-pro-and-celebrity-xiEx-Pro and Celebrity XIArsenal F.C11 August 2008https://web.archive.org/web/20080822031124/http://www.arsenal.com/the-club/community/ex-pro-and-celebrity-xi22 August 2008

In the 200910 season Arsenal announced that they had raised a record breaking 818,897 for theGreat Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity. The original target was 500,000.Arsenal smash fundraising target for GOSHArsenal FC, 2 August 2010
article.heading: Statistics and records
article.paragraph:
detailsList of Arsenal F.C. records and statisticsFile:Thierry Henry applauding 2012.jpgthumb150pxThierry Henryis Arsenal's record goalscorer, with 228 goals in all competitions.Arsenal's tally of 13 League Championships is the third highest in English football, after Manchester United (20) and Liverpool (18),cite webhttp://www.rsssf.com/tablese/engchamp.html#sall England – List of Champions RSSSF RossJames M 28 August 2009 23 October 2009
with a record of 12 FA Cup titles.cite webhttp://www.rsssf.com/tablese/engcuphist.html#sall England FA Challenge Cup Finals RSSSF RossJames M 12 June 2009 23 October 2009
Arsenal have achieved three League and FA Cup "Double (association football)#EnglandDoubles" (in 1971, 1998 and 2002), a feat only previously achieved by Manchester United (in 1994, 1996 and 1999),cite webhttp://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/doublerec.html#coun Doing the Double: Countrywise Records RSSSF StokkermansKarel 24 September 2009 23 October 2009
and in 1993 were the first side in English football to complete the FA Cup and League Cup double.cite newshttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2313666/Mourinho-collects-his-consolation-prize.html Mourinho collects his consolation prize RoyCollins The Daily Telegraph 20 May 20076 December 2009 Chelsea's Cup came wrapped in an extra ribbon, only the second team after Arsenal in 1993 to win both domestic cups. London
Arsenal were also the first London club to reach the final of the UEFA Champions League, in 2006, losing the final 21 toFC BarcelonaBarcelona.cite webhttp://www.premierleague.com/page/arsenal Arsenal Football Club Premier League 11 August 2008https://web.archive.org/web/20080913103452/http://www.premierleague.com/page/arsenal13 September 2008no

Arsenal have one of the best top-flight records in history, having finished below fourteenth only seven times. Arsenal also have the highest average league finishing position for the 20th century, with an average league placing of 8.5.cite newsFootball: How consistency and caution made Arsenal England's greatest team of the 20th centuryhttp://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-how-consistency-and-caution-made-arsenal-englands-greatest-team-of-the-20th-century-1133020.htmlThe Independent27 April 2012LondonGuyHodgson17 December 1999In addition, they are one of only six clubs to have won the FA Cup twice in succession, in 2002 and 2003, and 2014 and 2015.cite webhttp://www.rsssf.com/tablese/engcuphist.html England FA Challenge Cup Finals RSSSF RossJames M 12 June 2009 23 October 2009
Arsenal also hold the record for the longest unbeaten run in the Premier League at 49 games, and are the only team to have gone an entire Premier League season unbeaten in 200304.cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/history/club-records/the-unbeaten-recordThe Unbeaten RecordArsenal Broadband10 December 2011

David O'Learyholds the record for Arsenal appearances, having played 722 first-team matches between 1975 and 1993. Fellowcentre halfand former captainTony Adams (footballer)Tony Adamscomes second, having played 669 times. The record for agoalkeeper (association football)goalkeeperis held byDavid Seaman, with 564 appearances.cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/history/club-records Club Records Arsenal F.C 23 October 2009

Thierry Henryis the club's top goalscorer with 228 goals in all competitions between 1999 and 2012,cite newshttp://www.arsenal.com/history/club-records/goalscoring-records Goalscoring Records Arsenal.com 13 September 2013
having surpassedIan Wright's total of 185 in October 2005.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/a/arsenal/4356664.stm Wright salutes Henry's goal feat BBC Sport 19 October 2005 11 August 2008
Wright's record had stood since September 1997, when he overtook the longstanding total of 178 goals set by wingerCliff Bastinin 1939.cite webhttp://www.arseweb.com/97-98/reports/130997.html Arsenal vs Bolton. 13/09/97 Arseweb Ward, Rupert 11 August 2008
Henry also holds the club record for goals scored in the League, with 175,a record that had been held by Bastin until February 2006.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/4657206.stm Arsenal 2–3 West Ham BBC Sport 1 February 2006 23 October 2009

Arsenal's record home attendance is 73,707, for aUEFA Champions Leaguematch againstRC Lenson 25 November 1998 atWembley Stadium (1923)Wembley Stadium, where the club formerly played home European matches because of the limits on Highbury's capacity. The record attendance for an Arsenal match at Highbury is 73,295, for a 00 draw againstSunderland A.F.C.Sunderlandon 9 March 1935,while that at Emirates Stadium is 60,161, for a 22 draw with Manchester United on 3 November 2007.cite newshttp://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/man-utd-game-attracts-record-attendance Man Utd game attracts record attendance Arsenal F.C 5 November 2007 11 August 2008

Arsenal have also set records in English football, including the most consecutive seasons spent in the top flight (87 as of 201314) and the longest run of unbeaten League matches (49 between May 2003 and October 2004).This included all 38 matches of their title-winning200304 in English football200304season, when Arsenal became only the second club to finish a top-flight campaign unbeaten, afterPreston North End F.C.Preston North End(who played only 22 matches) in188889 in English football188889.

Arsenal also set a Champions League record during the 200506 season by going ten matches without conceding a goal, beating the previous best of seven set byA.C. Milan. They went a record total stretch of 995 minutes without letting an opponent score; the streak ended in2006 UEFA Champions League Finalthe final, whenSamuel Eto'oscored a 76th-minute equaliser for Barcelona.cite newshttp://www.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/history/season2005/06: Ronaldinho delivers for Barça UEFA 17 May 2007 11 August 2008
https://web.archive.org/web/20080915063506/http://www.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/history/season15 September 2008no

First-team squad

article.heading: UEFA Reserve squad
Former players

template.arg: a list of every Arsenal player with 100 or more appearances

article.heading: Current technical staff

link.part: Arsne Wenger, who has been managing Arsenal since 1996.

article.heading: Managers
article.paragraph: MainList of Arsenal F.C. managersThere have been eighteen permanent and fivecaretaker managersof Arsenal since the appointment of the club's first professional manager,Thomas Mitchell (football manager)Thomas Mitchellin 1897.cite bookSoar & TylerThe Official Illustrated History of Arsenal200530The club's longest-serving manager, in terms of both length of tenure and number of games overseen, isArsne Wenger, who was appointed in 1996.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8286929.stmWenger hungry for further successBBC Sport2 October 20096 December 2009cite newshttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1092959/700-Arsenal-boss-Wenger-looking-celebrate-memorable-day-Porto.html700 and not out: Arsenal boss Wenger looking to celebrate memorable day at PortoChristopherDaviesDaily MailUK8 December 20086 December 2009Wenger is also Arsenal's only manager from outside the United Kingdom.Two Arsenal managers have died in the job Herbert ChapmanandTom Whittaker (footballer)Tom Whittaker.cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/history/the-managersThe ManagersArsenal F.C7 September 2008https://web.archive.org/web/20080907001043/http://www.arsenal.com/history/the-managers7 September 2008no
article.heading: Honours
Domestic

list.listitem: Football League First DivisionFirst Division(until 1992) andPremier Leaguecite webArsenal.comwww.arsenal.comArsenal win their first league titlehttp://www.arsenal.com/history/herbert-chapman/arsenal-win-their-first-league-title16 Dec 200826 September 2015"Image at the top of the page shows 1931 team and their Trophy's, including the Football League First Division, FA Charity Shield, Sheriff of London Challenge Cup, London Challenge Cup, London Combination and anotherCite book[[Bernard Joy]]Forward, Arsenal!The Sportsmans Book Club1952https://books.google.co.uk/books?id0-9559211-1-2Cite bookMichael J SladeThe History of the English Football League: Part One—1888–1930Strategic Book Publishing2013https://books.google.co.uk/books?id1-62516-183-2Up until 1992, the top division ofFootball in EnglandEnglish footballwas theFootball League First Division; since then, it has been thePremier League. Similarly until 1992, theFootball League Second DivisionSecond Divisionwas the second tier of league football, which since the 200405 season has been known asFootball League ChampionshipThe Championship.

Winners (13):193031 in English football193031,193233 in English football193233,193334 in English football193334,193435 in English football193435,193738 in English football193738,194748 in English football194748,195253 in English football195253,197071 in English football197071,198889 in English football198889,199091 in English football199091,199798 FA Premier League199798,200102 FA Premier League200102,200304 FA Premier League200304

Winners (12):1930 FA Cup Final192930,1936 FA Cup Final193536,1950 FA Cup Final194950,1971 FA Cup Final197071,1979 FA Cup Final197879,1993 FA Cup Final199293,1998 FA Cup Final199798,2002 FA Cup Final200102,2003 FA Cup Final200203,2005 FA Cup Final200405,2014 FA Cup Final201314,2015 FA Cup Final201415(record)
Winners (2):1987 Football League Cup Final198687,1993 Football League Cup Final199293

FA Community Shield(FA Charity Shieldbefore 2002)The trophy was known as theFA Community ShieldCharity Shielduntil 2001, and as the Community Shield since then. Reference:cite webhttp://www.rsssf.com/tablese/engsupcuphist.htmlEngland – List of FA Charity/Community Shield MatchesRSSSFRossJames28 August 200912 January 2010 https://web.archive.org/web/20100113115022/http://rsssf.com/tablese/engsupcuphist.html13 January 2010no

Winners (14):1930,1931 FA Charity Shield1931, 1933,1934 FA Charity Shield1934, 1938,1948 FA Charity Shield1948,1953 FA Charity Shield1953,1991 FA Charity Shield1991(shared),1998 FA Charity Shield1998,1999 FA Charity Shield1999,2002 FA Community Shield2002,2004 FA Community Shield2004,2014 FA Community Shield2014,2015 FA Community Shield2015

article.heading: Arsenal Ladies
article.paragraph: detailsArsenal L.F.C.Arsenal L.F.C.Arsenal Ladiesare the women's football club affiliated to Arsenal. Founded in 1987, they turnedsemi-professionalin 2002 and are managed by Clare Wheatley.cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/ladies/coaching-staff/clare-wheatleyClare WheatleyArsenal FC16 March 2015Arsenal Ladies are the most successful team inWomen's football in EnglandEnglish women's football. In the 200809 season, they won all three major English trophies  theFA Women's Premier League,FA Women's CupandFA Women's Premier League Cup,cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/ladies/ladies-honoursArsenal Ladies HonoursArsenal F.C21 May 2007and, as of 2009, were the only English side to have won theUEFA Women's Cup, having done so in the 200607 season as part of a uniqueThe Quadruple#Women's Footballquadruple.cite webhttp://www.thefa.com/TheFACup/FACompetitions/TheFAWomensCup/NewsandFeatures/2009/FAWCMatchReport.aspxArsenal clinch quadrupleThe Football AssociationStuartMawhinney7 May 200723 October 2009https://web.archive.org/web/20091002150527/http://www.thefa.com/TheFACup/FACompetitions/TheFAWomensCup/NewsandFeatures/2009/FAWCMatchReport.aspx2 October 2009noThe men's and women's clubs are formally separate entities but have quite close ties; Arsenal Ladies are entitled to play once a season at the Emirates Stadium, though they usually play their home matches atBoreham Wood F.C.Boreham Wood.cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/ladies/boreham-wood-directionsGet to Boreham WoodArsenal F.C7 September 2008https://web.archive.org/web/20080906201612/http://www.arsenal.com/ladies/boreham-wood-directions6 September 2008no
